s.text: This hiss, the noise level in her voice, like Glenn Gould's humming as he played the piano or the squeaking of AndrŽs Segovia's fingers on the strings of his guitar, makes her unusual today, when most singers are trained in the discipline of steely perfection and when our ears have become accustomed to the sharp-edged sounds of a compact disc, surrounded by undiluted digital silence.
She can command a full, chesty holler when she needs to, but in quiet passages she tends to produce a gentle haze of breath around each focused note.
Does Bartoli live up to the hype?

) in a voice full of pain.
She colors the first recitative in her recording of Haydn's Orfeo ed Euridice with more brilliant hues of grief than I've ever heard before.
Another book about Bartoli and her contemporaries is being written by Manuela Hoelterhoff, the former opera critic of the Wall Street Journal , who is now a member of its editorial board.
